title: If your parents had no problem emotionally or physically abusing you as a child they’ll have no problem abusing you as an adult either

author: m00seabuse
text:
I finally had a drunky with my stepmom for the last time a few years back.  I started asking her how she could X and Y and Z, and she went on the understandable defensive.  She pulled out the big guns.  “I’m not going to feel bad about your life because you were such a horrible child.”

I finally said, “Bitch.  I was 10-14 through most of that mess.  You started the game at 48.  Who TF tells a kid they meet for the first time they are stupid, and then proceeds to ruin every ounce of their existence, and then sits back all “you were a horrible kid,”?  I think we’ve had about as much to say to one-another as life will allow.  Good luck to you and your addict POS son.  I hope he fails.”


Edit: The point is, I am now the age these people were when our journey started (well I am not 48 yet, but you get the point).  And I cannot imagine how these people ever thought their behavior was acceptable.  I cannot empathize with them enough to find a justification for it.

author: notmissingone
text: Please don't turn yourself into a pretzel trying to grasp someone's mental illness. You'll only mess yourself up.

author: CasualDefiance
text: I absolutely love your phrasing here. Turning onesself into a pretzel is exactly how it feels. Thank you for this.

author: m00seabuse
text: Took me a long time but I am learning.  But it gets really lonely when chaos is all you have known.  I work well under pressure and I come to life in abuse.  Pretty fked if you ask me.

author: spaghetti0223
text:
My nmom asked me a few years ago "Why were you such a bitch?" referring to my teen years.

It's how they justify the abuse. It's our fault. We deserved it.

BTW my response was simple: "I wasn't. I was a normal kid." She had no response to that.

author: thebabyshitter
text: mine still likes to call me a rude bitch to this day lol my standard response is "because you are such a loving mother"

author: [deleted]
text: I love your response!

author: TrashApocalypse
text:
Trying to cope with the abuse inflicted on me by my stepdad.... I was just a kid, and I’d *just* gotten my leg amputated by a lawnmower.

Who does that???

It truly is amazing to be an adult and to look back on these situations. I literally can’t imagine that anything was going through their mind, because they’re just shells of a human being at that point

author: m00seabuse
text: Omg your stepdad amputated you with a lawnmower?  Holy!

author: TrashApocalypse
text: No, he didn’t. It was an accident. But what he did wasn’t an accident.

author: No_Math653
text:
Do you and I have the same stepmother? I lived with her starting when I was 12, and she thought I was a terrible person from the start. The last time I spoke to mine, she asked me “If things were so bad, why didn’t you leave?”

Let’s see ... probably because my parents custody agreement said I HAD to live with my eDad? And because I was far too young to pack my things into a car and drive out of our town?
